awd_titl_txt: Understanding the Causes of Liquid Jet Atomization
awd_abstract_narration:
In spite of the accelerated development of electrification, particularly for automobiles, the global reliance on liquid fuels (bio-derived or petroleum based) continues to be strong. With the ongoing use of these fuels, a need exists for sustained improvements in pollutant reduction and fuel economy. A key place to look these advancements is directly in the process of fuel injection and spray formation. This area of investigation is not new, but unfortunately it has faced daunting experimental challenges originating from the presence of a dense cloud of minuscule droplets surrounding the liquid fuel core in the early stages of spray formation. It is precisely this early stage of fuel injection that is critical in the resulting spray characteristics and is ultimately linked to issues related to fuel economy and pollutant formation. An attractive alternative being pursued in the proposed work is the use of highly-detailed computer simulations that can adequately interrogate all stages of spray formation with sufficient spatial and temporal resolution. With these tools, long-standing questions concerning the dynamics of spray formation and their sensitivity to fuel properties and injection strategies will be addressed. A key question targeted in the proposed work concerns recently observed patterns of liquid fuel breakup, which seem to hint at some universal behavior of early-stage spray development. If these patterns can be understood, there is potential for controlling and optimizing them for maximum reduction of pollutant emissions and improvements in fuel economy. 

The proposed work aims to uncover the underlying causes of liquid jet breakup and provide a newer perspective to this relatively old problem by employing computer simulations. Preliminary simulation results have shown the emergence of a large-scale sinuous mode that is responsible for the atomization of the intact liquid core and is associated with the largest production of interfacial area and interphase momentum exchange. Hence, the main part of the proposed work begins with a quantitative examination of this large-scale mode. Explanation of the growth of this mode and other interfacial disturbances will then be pursued with a general instability theory and with a mathematical description based on potential flow theory (the intact liquid core is largely irrotational). To provide a more comprehensive analysis of the breakup phenomena, the simulation of the flow upstream of the injector nozzle will also be included. This upstream conditioning of the flow has been established as being a key feature in the development of interfacial instabilities and the breakup of the jet. Due to the challenges involved in the simulation of liquid sprays with interface capturing methods, new validation exercises will be undertaken, along with an automated means of evaluating the appropriateness of the numerical resolution employed.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
The injection of liquids at high pressures leading to the creation of finely atomized liquid sprays occurs in various applications, including agricultural fumigation, rocket engines, combustion of new low-carbon fuels in the transportation sector, liquid cooling of electronics, among other areas. Due to the violent hydrodynamic breakup process occurring very close to the injector nozzle, fundamental studies of the underlying dynamics have faced formidable challenges over the years. The continuous growth of computational power has made it possible nowadays to study the process of hydrodynamic breakup at an unprecedented level of detail using high-fidelity two-phase flow simulations. The approach taken in the present research is to combine these simulations with theoretical predictions based on spatial interfacial instability analysis and to focus the study on high-speed injection due to its industrial relevancy.

 

In previously published work, we reported that the most dominant and catastrophic flow feature consisted of a sinuous mode, which is responsible for fragmenting an injected liquid sheet or a liquid jet. However, the understanding of the dynamics governing the generation of the sinuous mode have remained elusive. Moreover, the phenomenon has been found to exist in both 3D and 2D configurations. To initially simplify the process and allow for much faster computations, a 2D configuration has been studied in the present work. By combining both stability theory with detailed two-phase flow computations, an explanation for the source of the sinuous mode has been found. It is rooted in the streamwise thickening of the shear layer, which promotes the growth of a large-scale sinuous mode over any other mode, including axisymmetric disturbances. The theoretical predictions have been successfully compared to the simulations, where the level of agreement was found to be within 3%. Moreover, an energy budget analysis has revealed that the dominant physical source for the destabilization of the sinuous mode is pressure fluctuations on the gas side. In contrast, these fluctuations were found to be suppressing the perturbation growth for the small-scale modes.

 

The principal elements of broader impact for this project are new educational initiatives, the involvement of members from under-represented groups, and the communication of fundamental knowledge to relevant industries. This has taken place through the participation of undergraduate students who spent summers at our lab as part of the UW-Madison Summer Undergraduate Research program. These students have been involved directly in computations relevant to the hydrodynamic phenomena targeted for study in the present work. Communication of fundamental knowledge to industries has occurred through our participation in the Direct-injection Engine Research Consortium, which hosts approximately 30 industry partners engaged in a wide variety of engine-related research. The contributions made in the current project to the fundamental knowledge of fuel injection have been a primary source of interest for our industry partners.

 


Last Modified: 09/25/2021
Modified by: Mario F Trujillo

    Mario F Trujillo
    Understanding the causes of liquid jet atomization
